intro: Agalinis setacea, commonly known as the slender false foxglove, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as prairies and sandy soils. The plant produces showy, tubular flowers that are often pink or purple, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. Its slender, erect stems are covered in fine hairs, and it has opposite, lance-shaped leaves. Agalinis setacea is often found in disturbed areas and is considered a short-lived perennial.
